Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Friendships, Identity Development, and Academic Adjustment in High School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
As U.S. adolescents become more ethnically diverse, all youths' social and academic success depends in part on their experiences with diverse peers in school. Among those from ethnic or racial minority backgrounds, having a strong Ethnic-Racial Identity is predictive of positive social and academic outcomes. Ethnic-Racial Identity (ERI) refers to a person's beliefs about and understanding of their own ethnicity or race and how their ethnicity or race relates to their sense of self. This research investigates not only how adolescents' own ERI shapes their experiences but also how the ERIs of their peers impacts their development. The study will provide important new insights into how adolescents' ERI unfolds and how adolescents' interactions with each other support positive educational outcomes during the high school years.

Longitudinal data will be collected from students in two high schools, each in a distinct geographical region of the U.S. Hypotheses will be tested regarding the extent to which ERI development occurs transactionally in the context of peer relationships as well as the role of individuals' and peers' ERI and peer relationship characteristics in adjustment. Youth with a stronger ERI and who have friends with a stronger ERI are expected to exhibit the most optimal outcomes, as they not only draw on their own internal resources but also benefit from by being embedded in a network of peers who can draw on similar resources. Peer relationship characteristics are expected to mediate associations between individuals' ERI and their adjustment over time, particularly for younger adolescents. The study will use innovative, longitudinal social network modeling methods. The implementation of this project will have a transformative effect on multiple fields by (a) impacting how researchers conceptualize and operationalize contextual influences on ERI development in future work; (b) increasing understanding of how contexts moderate and mediate the links between ERI and adjustment; (c) moving the field toward examining micro-informed mechanisms of peer network influence rather than focusing exclusively on selection and socialization processes, which dominates the current discourse in this area; and (d) serving as an exemplar of an interdisciplinary approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As U.S. adolescents become more ethnically diverse, all youths' social and academic success is likely to be shaped by their experiences with diverse peers in school. Among those from ethnic or racial minority backgrounds, having a strong ethnic-racial identity is predictive of positive social and academic outcomes. Ethnic-racial identity refers to a person's beliefs about and understanding of their own ethnicity or race and how their ethnicity or race relates to their sense of self. The Teen Identity Development and Education Study (TIDES) is a study focused on understanding the extent to which ethnic-racial identity development occurs transactionally in the context of peer relationships in school. We examine the role that adolescents' ethnic-racial identity plays in the process of friendship selection as well as the extent to which peers socialize one another with respect to their ethnic-racial identity development. We also explore how ethnic-racial identity informs the social and academic adjustment of diverse youth in these schools.

TIDES is an interdisciplinary collaboration led by Dr. Deborah Rivas-Drake at the University of Michigan and Dr. Adriana Umaña-Taylor at Harvard University, and was conducted in partnership with Dr. David Schaefer (UC Irvine) and Dr. Allison Ryan (University of Michigan) and the respective students of all investigators. Longitudinal data were collected from students in two high schools, each in a distinct geographical region of the U.S. Specifically, a total of 3,297 students were recruited from a high school in Arizona and 1,795 students were recruited from a high school in Michigan.

Primary outcomes include the successful training of 47 doctoral, Masters, and undergraduate students--the overwhelming majority of whom are from backgrounds underrepresented in higher education--and four postdoctoral scholars on the study preparation, recruitment, data collection, and data cleaning phases of the project. Postdoctoral fellows also developed skills in the management of a large-scale dataset and were trained in or implemented social network analysis. Another important outcome related to research training is the delivery of a four-week research curriculum to high school students via a summer internship at the University of Michigan, in which youth made meaningful connections with TIDES research by learning more about the "why" of the project's design and methodology and designing their own research proposals on related topics.

Preliminary findings from the study have been disseminated at national and international conferences in the form of three paper presentations and five poster presentations. In addition, three manuscripts are currently undergoing peer review for publication. Moreover, one dissertation at the University of Michigan and one undergraduate Senior Honors Thesis at the University of California have been completed using data from the TIDES project, and several more TIDES-based dissertations at Harvard University and the University of Michigan are currently underway.

Finally, the investigative team recently received a new NSF award for a project that leverages data from TIDES with supplemental archival data. The new project examines innovative research questions exploring how adolescents' phenotypic characteristics, ethnic-racial identity, friendship networks, and extracurricular activity participation coalesce to inform school-wide patterns of ethnoracial segregation.
